speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about when these episodes of unresponsiveness started happening? Was there a specific trigger or event that led to them?

speaker: Patient
text: "It started about a month ago, I think. My brother saw me doing something weird and I don't remember it, but he said I was staring and making my hands move like I was trying to say something. I just felt really tired and confused afterwards."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your daily activities and routine around the time these episodes started? Do you engage in any strenuous physical activities, use any medications, or have any pre-existing medical conditions that might be contributing to this?

speaker: Patient
text: "I usually go to school and play with my friends, and I don't think anything changed in my routine. My mom says I've been eating the same foods I usually do, and I don't think I've taken any new medicines. I did eat some muddy-looking dirt in my backyard a few times, but my mom said that's not good for me."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the muddy-looking dirt you've been eating? Was it from your own backyard or someone else's? Also, when you say you don't remember the episodes, do you have any gaps in your memory before or after these episodes, like anything you might have done or seen that's not clear to you?

speaker: Patient
text: "I don't know, it was just dirt. My mom said it was from our backyard, but I don't really remember. I just thought it looked like mud and I wanted to taste it. I don't think I've eaten it every day, just a few times. And about the memory... I don't really remember anything before or after the episodes. I just wake up and my mom is there, telling me what happened. Sometimes I feel confused for a little while, but then I'm okay."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you describe the facial grimacing you experience during these episodes? Is it a specific expression, like a grimace or a contortion of your face, or is it more of a general tightening of your facial muscles? Also, REQUEST TEST: Electroencephalogram (EEG)

speaker: Doctor

speaker: Patient
text: "Hmm, I don't really know what 'interictal' means, but my mom said something about it being related to the tests you did. As for the sensations before the episodes, I don't really feel anything, but sometimes I get a weird, bitter taste in my mouth. speaker: Doctor
text: It sounds like your brain is trying to tell us something, but we need to listen more closely. Can you tell me more about this "bitter taste" you mentioned? speaker: Patient
text: "It's not really a taste, I guess. It's more like... my mouth feels all weird and stuffy, like someone poured something in there. It's hard to explain. And, yeah, it happens during the episodes, but sometimes it's there too when I'm not having an episode, but it's not really a taste, it's more like... a feeling, I don't know. *makes a funny face again*"

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your family history? Have any of your relatives had similar episodes or conditions that might be contributing to your symptoms?

speaker: Patient
text: "Uh, my mom's mom had something weird happen to her sometimes, I think. She would just stare and do weird things, but my mom said it was just because she was old and had bad memory. And my grandma had seizures when she was little, but my mom said it was just because she was sick, not because of anything like this. I don't know, it's not really like that, but I don't think anyone else in my family has anything like this, I guess."

speaker: Doctor

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the episodes themselves? How long do they typically last, and what happens after they're over? Do you ever feel like you're coming back to yourself, or is it more like you're waking up from a dream?

It's weird, because sometimes I feel like I'm coming back to myself, but it's not really like I remember anything, so it's hard to explain."
